answers.q: is potassium sorbate bad for you
answers.a: Generally no; potassium sorbate (E202) is a low-toxicity preservative approved by major regulators, though high concentrations can irritate and rare sensitivities occur.
Yes—it's considered safe at permitted food levels by authorities like FDA, EFSA, and JECFA; occasional mild sensitivities have been reported.

answers.q: how much potassium sorbate per gallon of mead
answers.a: Typically about 0.6–1.0 g per US gallon (≈150–250 mg/L) to inhibit refermentation; add after fermentation is complete and alongside sulfite.

answers.q: how much potassium sorbate per gallon of wine
answers.a: Commonly about 0.6–1.0 g per US gallon (≈150–250 mg/L); use with sulfite and check any local limits on sorbate levels.
Yes—it's a synthetic preservative and contains no gluten, so it's suitable for people with celiac disease.
